book_overview: Sinful leaders will bring God's wrath and almost destroy the world, but his servants will be saved for life in the new earth
ESV_summary: "The revelation of Jesus Christ" (1:1) was probably written by the apostle John while in exile on the island of Patmos, off the coast of present-day Turkey. It was addressed to seven actual churches. Revelation begins with letters from Christ himself to these churches, letters that include commendation, criticism, and comfort. Then comes a long series of visions of judgment on the wicked, all in highly symbolic language. The church is depicted under great distress but is assured of the final triumph of Jesus as "King of kings and Lord of lords" (19:16), bringing to an end the rebellion of humanity and ushering in "a new heaven and a new earth" (21:1), where God himself will reign forever and ever (11:15). Revelation was probably written AD 95–96.
ESV_introduction: This last book of the Bible identifies itself as "the revelation of Jesus Christ", and its author is designated "his servant John" who was exiled to the Greek island of Patmos because of his faith. Traditionally, John is identified with the author of the Fourth Gospel. Addressed to seven historical churches in Asia Minor, the Book of Revelation was written to warn against spiritual indifference and to elicit courage under persecution. Because of the extensive use of symbolism and picturesque imagery, its interpretation has posed many problem for the student of the Bible. While recognizing the historical situation (Roman persecution) that elicited this writing, many interpreters look upon it as a prophecy depicting events that were to take place at the end of the age. The ultimate victory of Christ is the dominant theme of this book.
chapter_1_overview: The revelation of Jesus Christ to John. A voice said, "Write to the churches." I saw one like a son of man, his face was like the sun.
chapter_1_summary: John addresses seven churches in Asia Minor (modern-day Turkey). He describes a vision of Jesus Christ, who appears glorified, with white hair, eyes like flames, and a voice like rushing waters. Jesus holds seven stars and walks among seven lampstands, representing the churches. John is instructed to write down what he sees and send it to the churches.
chapter_2_description: Letters to Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, Thyatira
chapter_2_overview: "Ephesus, renew your first love. Smyrna, be faithful until death. Pergamum, some hold false teaching. Thyatira, you tolerate Jezebel."
chapter_2_summary:
John records messages from Jesus to the first four of seven churches.
Ephesus: Jesus commends the church for its hard work, but criticizes it for losing its first love - calling for repentance and reminding them to return to their initial passion for God.
Smyrna: Jesus encourages the church in Smyrna, acknowledging their suffering and poverty, but assuring them of their spiritual richness. He warns of impending persecution, but promises the crown of life to those who remain faithful.
Pergamum: Jesus acknowledges the faithfulness of the church in Pergamum despite living in a city where Satan has his throne. However, He criticizes them for allowing false teachings and immorality to spread, urging them to repent.
Thyatira: Jesus praises the church for its love and service, but condemns it for tolerating a false prophetess who leads believers into sexual immorality. He warns of judgment if they do not repent.
chapter_3_overview: "Sardis, you are not alive but dead. Philadelphia, you have endured in my word. Laodicea, you are lukewarm so I will spit you out."
chapter_3_summary:
John continues with messages from Christ to the remaining three churches:
Sardis: Jesus warns the church in Sardis that it appears alive but is spiritually dead. He calls them to wake up, strengthen what remains, and remember the teachings they received.
Philadelphia: Jesus commends the faithful church in Philadelphia for their perseverance and promises to protect them during the time of trial. He assures them that those who are not true believers will acknowledge them as God's people.
Laodicea: Jesus rebukes the lukewarm church in Laodicea; they don’t have the benefits of heat nor cold. He urges them to become zealous and repent, inviting them to open the door of their hearts, promising fellowship to those who overcome.
chapter_4_overview: I saw one seated on the throne in heaven. The four living creatures say, "Holy, holy, holy." The elders say, "You created all things."
chapter_4_summary: John describes a vision of heaven, where he sees a throne and the one seated on it, surrounded by 24 elders and four living creatures. The elders wear crowns and worship God, proclaiming His holiness..
chapter_5_description: The lamb and the sealed scroll
chapter_5_overview: A Lamb standing as though slain took the scroll with seven seals. The creatures, elders and myriad angels sang, "Worthy is the Lamb!"
chapter_5_summary: John sees a scroll sealed with seven seals. No one is found worthy to open it until the Lamb who was slain appears - one who is worthy to open the scroll. The elders and living creatures worship the Lamb, praising Him for redemption and the establishment of a kingdom.
chapter_6_description: Opening of the first six seals
chapter_6_overview: The Lamb opened four seals and the horsemen went out to destroy. With the fifth seal I saw the martyrs. With the sixth the stars fell.
chapter_6_summary: Describes the opening of the first six seals on the scroll. The first seal reveals a white horse and a rider who conquers. The second brings a red horse, symbolizing war and bloodshed. The third reveals a black horse, representing famine. The fourth brings a pale horse, whose rider is Death. The fifthshows the souls of martyrs crying out for justice.The sixth brings cosmic disturbances, such as earthquakes and darkening of the sun.
chapter_7_description: The sealed multitude from every nation
chapter_7_overview: The 144,000 were sealed from the tribes. A multitude cried, "Salvation belongs to our God." An elder said, "God will wipe every tear."
chapter_7_summary: John sees an angel sealing 144,000 servants of God from the tribes of Israel, ensuring their protection during the coming judgments. He then sees a great multitude from every nation, tribe, people, and language standing before the throne and the Lamb, praising God and expressing their salvation.
chapter_8_description: Seventh seal and first four trumpets
chapter_8_overview: With the seventh seal there was silence. I saw seven angels. Four angels blew their trumpets and a third of the earth was destroyed.
chapter_8_summary: The seventh seal is opened, leading to silence in heaven for half an hour. Seven angels are given trumpets to sound, signaling the coming judgments.
chapter_9_overview: At the fifth trumpet, locusts from the pit tormented the earth. At the sixth trumpet, four angels killed a third of mankind with fire.
chapter_9_summary: The fifth trumpet sounds, and a star falls from heaven, unlocking the Abyss. Locusts emerge, tormenting those who do not have the seal of God on their foreheads. The sixth trumpet releases four angels bound at the Euphrates River, leading to the killing of a third of mankind. Despite these judgments, many still do not repent of their sins.
chapter_10_description: The angel and the little scroll
chapter_10_overview: I saw an angel with a scroll. He cried out and seven thunders sounded. A voice said, "Eat the scroll." It was sweet and then bitter.
chapter_10_summary: John sees, descending from heaven, a mighty angel with a rainbow over his head and a face like the sun. He stands on land and sea, holding a little scroll that is open. The angel shouts, and when he does, seven thunders respond. John is instructed not to write down what the thunders say. The angel then declares that there will be no more delay, and the mystery of God will be fulfilled. John is told to take the little scroll from the angel and eat it; it tastes sweet in his mouth but is bitter in his stomach..
chapter_11_overview: The two witnesses will prophesy until the beast kills them. At the seventh trumpet, loud voices said, "Our God shall reign forever."
chapter_11_summary: The two witnesses, who prophesy for 1,260 days, clothed in sackcloth. They are described as the two olive trees and two lampstands before God. These witnesses have the power to perform miracles, such as shutting the sky and turning water into blood. After their testimony, they are killed by a beast that arises from the abyss. Their bodies lie in the street of Jerusalem, which is symbolically called Sodom and Egypt. After three and a half days, God resurrects them, and they ascend to heaven. The chapter concludes with the sounding of the seventh trumpet, announcing God's kingdom and judgment.
chapter_12_overview: A woman giving birth and a great dragon appeared. Michael and his angels fought the dragon. The dragon was thrown down to the earth.
chapter_12_summary: John sees a vision of a woman who is about to give birth, and a great red dragon that seeks to devour her child.The dragon is defeated by Michael and his angels, and is cast down to the earth - where he continues to persecute the woman and her offspring.
chapter_13_description: The beast from sea and land
chapter_13_overview: I saw a beast rising out of the sea. It spoke blasphemy against God. Another beast rose and gave everyone a mark. Its number is 666.
chapter_13_summary: Introduces two beasts that rise up, the first with seven heads and ten horns emerges from the sea, and is given authority by the dragon to rule the world. The second beast, coming from the earth, deceives people and forces them to worship the first beast.
chapter_14_description: The lamb and the final harvest
chapter_14_overview: I saw the Lamb in Zion with the 144,000. Angels said, "The hour of judgement has come." The earth was reaped with a sharp sickle.
chapter_14_summary: John sees a vision of the lamb standing on Mount Zion with the 144,000 who were sealed in Chapter 7. An angel proclaims the eternal gospel, warning people to fear God and worship Him. Another angel announces the fall of Babylon, the great city that has corrupted the earth. John sees the Son of Man reaping the harvest of the earth.
chapter_15_overview: I saw angels with seven plagues. Those who conquered sang, "Just are your ways, Lord!" The angels were given seven bowls of wrath.
chapter_15_summary: John sees another sign in heaven: seven angels with seven plagues, which are the last plagues because with them God’s wrath is completed. The victorious ones who have overcome the beast sing a song of praise to God. They stand by a sea of glass mixed with fire, symbolizing God's judgment and purity.
chapter_16_overview: The bowls of wrath were poured out. The seas turned to blood, darkness fell, the kings gathered at Armageddon and the earth quaked.
chapter_16_summary: The seven angels pour out the seven bowls of God's wrath. The first bowl causes painful sores, the second turns the sea to blood, the third contaminates the fresh water, the fourth scorches people with fire, the fifth plunges the kingdom of the beast into darkness, the sixth dries up the Euphrates River, and the seventh brings a great earthquake and hail.
chapter_17_overview: I saw a prostitute on a beast with seven heads and ten horns. An angel said, "The heads and horns are kings. The Lamb will conquer."
chapter_17_summary: One of the angels shows John the judgment of the great prostitute, who sits on many waters.. This woman is described as being drunk with the blood of saints and is associated with Babylon, representing moral corruption and idolatry. The beast she rides has seven heads and ten horns; and the two of them will ultimately face judgment and destruction.
chapter_18_overview: An angel cried, "Fallen, fallen is Babylon!" The kings and merchants will weep. An angel said, "The great city will be thrown down."
chapter_18_summary: An angel from heaven proclaims the destruction of Babylon, declaring that it has become a dwelling place for demons and a haunt for unclean spirits. The reasons for Babylon's fall are highlighted, including its luxury, immorality, and persecution of God’s people. The kings of the earth, merchants, and sailors mourn the destruction of Babylon because they profited from her corruption. They witness her downfall from a distance and lament the loss of their wealth and the great city. God's people are called to come out of Babylon, warning them not to share in her sins and to escape her judgment.
chapter_19_overview: A multitude cried, "Hallelujah! The Lord reigns." The Word of God led the armies of heaven. The beast was cast into the lake of fire.
chapter_19_summary: John sees a great multitude in heaven praising God for His judgment on Babylon. They rejoice because God has avenged the blood of His servants. The Marriage Supper of the Lamb is described, where Jesus will be united with His bride, the church. John sees Jesus coming on a white horse, called "Faithful and True." He judges and makes war with righteousness. His eyes are like blazing fire, and He wears many crowns. The armies of heaven follow Him, and He strikes down nations with His word..
chapter_20_overview: Satan was bound and the martyrs reigned with Christ for 1,000 years. Then Satan was cast into the lake of fire. The dead were judged.
chapter_20_summary: John describes the binding of Satan for a thousand years, during which he cannot deceive the nations. The saints who had been martyred for their faith come to life and reign with Christ during this period. After the thousand years, Satan is released and deceives the nations one last time, gathering them for battle. However, fire comes down from heaven and consumes them. Satan is then thrown into the lake of fire, where the beast and the false prophet have already been cast. Then comes the Great White Throne Judgment, where the dead are judged according to their deeds. Anyone whose name is not found in the Book of Life is thrown into the lake of fire..
chapter_21_description: A New heaven and a new earth
chapter_21_overview: I saw a new heaven and earth. A voice said, "God dwells with his people." An angel showed me the new Jerusalem. Its lamp is the Lamb.
chapter_21_summary: A vision of a new heaven and a new earth, as the first heaven and earth have passed away. The new Jerusalem descends from heaven, prepared as a bride adorned for her husband. God dwells among His people, wiping away every tear and removing pain and death. John describes the beauty of the city, with streets of gold and gates made of pearls. Nothing impure will enter this city, only those whose names are written in the Lamb’s Book of Life. This new creation is the fulfillment of God’s promises to His people.
chapter_22_description: River of life and Christ's return
chapter_22_overview: The river of life flows from the throne of God. "Behold, I am coming soon. I am the beginning and the end." Amen. Come, Lord Jesus!
chapter_22_summary: John describes the river of life, flowing from the throne of God in the new Jerusalem. On either side of the river stands the Tree of Life, which bears fruit every month and whose leaves are for the healing of the nations.There will be no more curse, and God’s servants will see His face. Jesus declares, "I am coming soon." Amen.
